label: abbreviation
description: A shortened form of a word or phrase, such as an [initialism](#initialism), [acronym](#acronym), or [clipping](#clipping).

label: acronym
description: An [abbreviation](#abbreviation), usually formed from the initial letters of a phrase, that is pronounced as the “word” it would spell, such as [_NATO_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/NATO#English). / Contrast an [initialism](#initialism), where the letters are pronounced individually, and a [syllabic abbreviation](#syllabic_abbreviation), which is formed from syllables (rather than letters) of the underlying phrase.

label: expression
description: Applying the correct language to an argument.

label: proverb
description: A [phrase](#phrase) expressing a basic truth which may be applied to common situations.

label: sentence
description: A syntactic unit that expresses a complete thought and consists of one or more [clauses](#clause) joined together.

label: neologism
description: A newly coined word or expression.

label: gloss
description: A brief explanation or definition of a word or phrase.

label: agent
description: The (actual, real) initiator of the action.

label: denotation
description: The literal primary meaning of a word, in contrast to the feelings or ideas that the word suggests.

label: attribute
description: A quality or feature regarded as a characteristic or inherent part of someone or something.

label: augmentative
description: A word with an enlarged meaning or with a coarser meaning compared to the neutral related word.

label: diminutive
description: A word with a small meaning compared to the neutral related word.

label: doublet
description: Two or more words in a language that have different forms but the same etymological root.

label: anthroponym
description: A proper name of an individual person or group of people.

label: ethnonym
description: A proper name of a tribe or nation.

label: hypocoric
description: A domestic or pet name, sometimes also shortened.

label: calque
description: A word or phrase borrowed from another language by literal word-for-word or root-for-root translation.
